source_paper.title: Surveillance in Ulcerative Colitis: Is It Worthwhile? Does It Save Lives?
source_paper.abstract: Surveillance means to “watch over,” usually with the aim of detecting something sinister. Cancer surveillance in colitis should, ideally, be a program of regular investigation to detect precancerous changes so that cancer can be avoided by timely surgery. As a second best result, a surveillance investigation may detect carcinoma, but this should not be the prime aim since invasive malignancy is always dangerous. Using dysplasia as a marker, the ideal of detecting precancerous changes is not possible in all cases but, using a combination of newly available genetic markers, this should be the aim. tial difference is that patients with colitis are seeking medical help for their condition. Surveillance is just one aspect of the total clinical care of such patients. Surveillance is not synonymous with colonoscopy. Regular limited examination of the distal bowel could be used to detect early cancer and/or dysplasia (see below), although recognized as being an incomplete examination of the large intestine.
